meeting_annotations.speaker: Greeshma Gadikota
meeting_annotations.transcript: So I have a question that is perhaps a little more fundamental. In the context of direct air capture, how important are entropic contributions like in terms of the energetic input, should we even does it even make sense for us to think about engineering materials for from an entropic capture point of view or does it simply make sense for us to just think about trying to engineer the enthalpic component of it. That is so I wasn't sure what the current thinking is along those lines.
meeting_annotations.other: There is a notable 4-second pause after she finishes, suggesting the group is deeply considering her complex question.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Chris Jones
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think the conventional wisdom in the literature thus far has focused on enthalpy because it is more straightforward and tractable. I think there is good science to be done by looking at the entropic contributions and I think that area is less explored.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jarad Mason
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah I mean I think you pay a really large entropic penalty for CO2 going from being free in the gas phase to confined on a surface and so if you can do anything by inducing an increase in the entropy of a material when it binds CO2 to kind of compensate for that then you can favor the absorption of more CO2 and potentially reach higher capacities at these lower partial pressures. But like Chris said I think it is a very unexplored kind of area. It's less obvious to me I mean usually the enthalpy and entropy of absorption should be quite highly correlated because the more stronger the binding site you have for the gas the more constrained it is going to be on the surface and so there's usually not that much you can really do which is why maybe it makes sense just to focus on binding energy because the entropy is just going to kind of tag along. But that's where I think if you have more dynamic adsorbents or sorbents and things that respond and are not just inert materials but actually change in terms of the dynamics or structure as a function of CO2 partial pressure then you open up opportunities for thinking about engineering entropy.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Chris Jones
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think a lot of classical adsorbents if you go to textbooks right are solid rigid materials where the entropy of adsorption on the surface at different sites is not terribly different. But a lot of the dynamic materials whether it be the moffs that you're familiar with Jared from your past history or solid ionic liquid hybrids, supported liquid phases, polymeric structures that have chain mobility, those are all things where you can engineer the entropic term such that you have very different entropies of adsorption.
